paragraphs.text:
%md
# Load Data
First we load the data from S3. We use the built-in "csv" method, which can use the first line has column names and which also supports infering the schema automatically. We use both and save some code for specifying the schema explictly.

We also peek inside the data by retrieving the first five records.

Load Data

First we load the data from S3. We use the built-in “csv” method, which can use the first line has column names and which also supports infering the schema automatically. We use both and save some code for specifying the schema explictly.

We also peek inside the data by retrieving the first five records.

// Split the data - 80% for training, 20% for validation
val Array(trainData, validationData) = rawData.randomSplit(Array(0.8,0.2))

println(s"traingData = ${trainData.count}")
println(s"validationData = ${validationData.count}")

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Create Pipeline

We reuse the long pipeline from last time. This time we want to tweak additional parameters, so called *Hyper-Parameters*

msg.data:
Create Pipeline

We reuse the long pipeline from last time. This time we want to tweak additional parameters, so called Hyper-Parameters

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.ml.feature._
import org.apache.spark.ml.regression._


val stages = Array(
    new StringIndexer()
        .setInputCol("bathrooms")
        .setOutputCol("bathrooms_idx")
        .setHandleInvalid("keep"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("bathrooms_idx")
        .setOutputCol("bathrooms_onehot"),
    new StringIndexer()
        .setInputCol("bedrooms")
        .setOutputCol("bedrooms_idx")
        .setHandleInvalid("keep"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("bedrooms_idx")
        .setOutputCol("bedrooms_onehot"),
    new StringIndexer()
        .setInputCol("floors")
        .setOutputCol("floors_idx")
        .setHandleInvalid("keep"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("floors_idx")
        .setOutputCol("floors_onehot"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("view")
        .setOutputCol("view_onehot"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("condition")
        .setOutputCol("condition_onehot"),
    new StringIndexer()
        .setInputCol("grade")
        .setOutputCol("grade_idx")
        .setHandleInvalid("keep"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("grade_idx")
        .setOutputCol("grade_onehot"),
    new StringIndexer()
        .setInputCol("zipcode")
        .setOutputCol("zipcode_idx")
        .setHandleInvalid("keep"),
    new OneHotEncoder()
        .setInputCol("zipcode_idx")
        .setOutputCol("zipcode_onehot"),
    new VectorAssembler()
        .setInputCols(Array("bedrooms_onehot", "bathrooms_onehot", "sqft_living", "sqft_lot", "floors_onehot", "waterfront", "view_onehot", "condition_onehot", "grade_onehot", "sqft_above", "sqft_basement", "yr_built", "yr_renovated", "zipcode_onehot", "sqft_living15", "sqft_lot15"))
        .setOutputCol("features"),
    new LinearRegression()
        .setFeaturesCol("features")
        .setLabelCol("price")
        .setPredictionCol("linear_prediction"),
    new GeneralizedLinearRegression()
        .setFeaturesCol("features")
        .setLabelCol("price")
        .setFamily("poisson")
        .setLink("log")
        .setPredictionCol("poisson_prediction"),
    new VectorAssembler()
        .setInputCols(Array("linear_prediction","poisson_prediction"))
        .setOutputCol("pred_features"),
    new LinearRegression()
        .setFeaturesCol("pred_features")
        .setLabelCol("price")
        .setPredictionCol("prediction")
    
)

val pipe = new Pipeline().setStages(stages)

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Hyper Parameter Tuning

The whole pipeline has some parameters which have an influence on the result, i.e. the accuracy. For example the size of the n-grams will probably have a big impact and also the minDF parameter of the CountVecttorizer will probably have some impact. These settings are called "hyper parameters", because they are also model parameters, but not learnt directly during the training phase. But which parameters work best?

We will use a CrossValidation to select the best set of hyperparameters.

msg.data:
Hyper Parameter Tuning

The whole pipeline has some parameters which have an influence on the result, i.e. the accuracy. For example the size of the n-grams will probably have a big impact and also the minDF parameter of the CountVecttorizer will probably have some impact. These settings are called “hyper parameters”, because they are also model parameters, but not learnt directly during the training phase. But which parameters work best?

We will use a CrossValidation to select the best set of hyperparameters.

res276: String =
aggregationDepth: suggested depth for treeAggregate (>= 2) (default: 2)
elasticNetParam: the ElasticNet mixing parameter, in range [0, 1]. For alpha = 0, the penalty is an L2 penalty. For alpha = 1, it is an L1 penalty (default: 0.0)
featuresCol: features column name (default: features, current: features)
fitIntercept: whether to fit an intercept term (default: true)
labelCol: label column name (default: label, current: price)
maxIter: maximum number of iterations (>= 0) (default: 100)
predictionCol: prediction column name (default: prediction, current: linear_prediction)
regParam: regularization parameter (>= 0) (default: 0.0)
solver: the solver algorithm for optimization. If this is not set or empty, default value is 'auto' (default: auto)
standardization: whether to ...

res277: String =
family: The name of family which is a description of the error distribution to be used in the model. Supported options: gaussian, poisson, binomial, gamma, tweedie. (default: gaussian, current: poisson)
featuresCol: features column name (default: features, current: features)
fitIntercept: whether to fit an intercept term (default: true)
labelCol: label column name (default: label, current: price)
link: The name of link function which provides the relationship between the linear predictor and the mean of the distribution function. Supported options: cloglog, probit, logit, inverse, sqrt, identity, log (current: log)
linkPower: The index in the power link function. Only applicable to the Tweedie family. (undefined)
linkPredictionCol: link prediction (linear predictor) col...

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Create ParamGrid

Now we create a param grid that should be used for using different sets of parameters. We want to tweak three parameters:

* `elasticNetParam` of first LinearRegression  should take values in [0.25,0.5,0.75]
* `regParam` of first LinearRegression  should take values in [0.01, 0.1, 0.3]
* `link` opf the GeneralizedLinearRegression should take values in ["identity", "log"])

In order to create this grid, we first need to retrieve the corresponding stages from the pipeline, so we can access its parameters.

msg.data:
Create ParamGrid

Now we create a param grid that should be used for using different sets of parameters. We want to tweak three parameters:

  • elasticNetParam of first LinearRegression should take values in [0.25,0.5,0.75]
  • regParam of first LinearRegression should take values in [0.01, 0.1, 0.3]
  • link opf the GeneralizedLinearRegression should take values in [“identity”, “log”])

In order to create this grid, we first need to retrieve the corresponding stages from the pipeline, so we can access its parameters.

paragraphs.text:
import org.apache.spark.ml.tuning.ParamGridBuilder

val linearRegression = stages(13)
val generalizedLinearRegression = stages(14)

val param_grid = new ParamGridBuilder()
    .addGrid(linearRegression.getParam("elasticNetParam"), Seq(0.25, 0.5, 0.75))
    .addGrid(linearRegression.getParam("regParam"), Seq(0.01, 0.1, 0.3))
    .addGrid(generalizedLinearRegression.getParam("link"), Seq("identity", "log"))
    .build()

import org.apache.spark.ml.evaluation._
import org.apache.spark.ml.tuning._

val evaluator = new RegressionEvaluator()
    .setLabelCol("price")
    .setPredictionCol("prediction")
    .setMetricName("rmse")

// Create a CrossValidator instance
val validator = new CrossValidator()
    .setEstimator(pipe)
    .setEstimatorParamMaps(param_grid)
    .setEvaluator(evaluator)
    .setNumFolds(3)

msg.data:

import org.apache.spark.ml.tuning._

validator: org.apache.spark.ml.tuning.CrossValidator = cv_2cf3769d676d

paragraphs.text:
val pred = model.transform(validationData)
val rmse = evaluator.evaluate(pred)

println(s"RMSE = $rmse")
